title: 108_hr4550
content: The Act titled "Safe, Efficient, Coordinated, Unified, Revitalized, Enhanced Visa Waiver Act" requires visa waiver participants to electronically submit biographical information. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish an electronic system for visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information before entering the United States without a visa. The electronic system for visa waiver program participants must provide an electronic determination of eligibility within 30 minutes for nonimmigrant visitors to the United States. The system for visa waiver program participants must include a method for carriers to electronically inquire about an alien passenger's eligibility for admission, with a response provided in 90 seconds or less. Deployment of the system should be done promptly. The system for visa waiver program participants must include a method for carriers to electronically inquire about an alien passenger's eligibility for admission in 90 seconds or less. Deployment of the system should be prompt, and a fee will be charged to cover the costs. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consult with a private sector group during the system's development. Homeland Security must consult with a private sector group of experts in travel, tourism, privacy, national security, or computer security for the review of the visa waiver program system. SEC. 3. CHANGE TO REQUIREMENT FOR READERS AND SCANNERS AT PORTS OF ENTRY. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act requires the installation of equipment and software at all ports of entry into the United States for biometric comparison and authentication of visas and travel documents issued to aliens by October 26, 2004. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act mandates the installation of equipment and software at all U.S. ports of entry by October 26, 2005, for biometric comparison and authentication of passports issued to aliens. SEC. 4 amends the deadline for technology standard implementation to 2005. SEC. 5 provides a limited good faith waiver. Section 303(c) of the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant up to 2 extensions for a country and its nationals towards passport issuance deadlines if substantial progress is being made. The Secretary of Homeland Security can grant up to 2 extensions for a country's passport issuance deadlines if substantial progress is being made, considering specific factors certified by the Secretary of State. The Secretary of State certifies specific factors to determine if a country has made efforts to meet passport issuance deadlines. The pilot program will issue passports meeting requirements before March 26, 2006. Reports on countries' progress are due by October 26, 2005, and a final report by April 25, 2006. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, must issue a final report by April 25, 2006, on countries' progress in meeting passport requirements. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends Section 303 of the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act to replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security".
